# Ubuntu 16.04

Ubuntu`Ctrl+Alt+T`

## git

```
sudo apt install git
```

 git

```
git config --global user.name  "ZHANG Ying"
git config --global user.email "your@email.com"
git config --global core.autocrlf input  # trueLFCRLFfalse
```

git`~/.ssh` keyGithubpublic key

## node.js

a. Node.js https://nodejs.org/en/download/ Linux-x64`/usr/local/`

```
cd ~
ver=v6.9.2
wget https://nodejs.org/dist/${ver}/node-${ver}-linux-x64.tar.xz

tar axf node-${ver}-linux-x64.tar.xz
cd node-${ver}-linux-x64/
sudo cp -r ./ /usr/local/
cd ..
rm -rf node-${ver}-linux-x64.tar.xz
```

b. 
[Installing Node.js via package manager](https://nodejs.org/en/download/package-manager/)

```
curl -sL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_6.x | sudo -E bash -
sudo apt install -y nodejs

sudo apt install -y build-essential #npmgcc
```

## hexo

```
sudo npm install hexo-cli -g
```

##  `_config.yml`

 `_config.yml` deployrepo

```
## Themes: https://hexo.io/themes/
theme: jane

# Deployment
## Docs: https://hexo.io/docs/deployment.html
deploy:
  type: git
  repository: git@github.com:ying-zhang/ying-zhang.github.io.git
  branch: master
```

## 
`hexo-math`
```
{% math %}
\begin{align*}
-\sum_i{P_i\log_2\frac{P_i}{Q_i}} =& \sum_i{P_i\log_2\frac{Q_i}{P_i}} \\
\le& \log_2\sum_i{P_i\frac{Q_i}{P_i}} \tag{Jensen } \\
=& \log_2\sum_i{Q_i} \\
=& 0
\end{align*}
{% endmath %}
```

{% math %}
\begin{align*}
-\sum_i{P_i\log_2\frac{P_i}{Q_i}} =& \sum_i{P_i\log_2\frac{Q_i}{P_i}} \\
\le& \log_2\sum_i{P_i\frac{Q_i}{P_i}} \tag{Jensen } \\
=& \log_2\sum_i{Q_i} \\
=& 0
\end{align*}

## SELinux

setenforce 0
```

```

```

```

> PXE  dhcpIPTFTPHTTPIP TFTPHTTPKickstart
cobbler_web cobblerHTTP

## root
```
openssl passwd -1 -salt "centos" "centos"
# salt
$1$centos$Uq6E6Wp5SDZYbs6MCmamP0
```

# cobbler
```
vi /etc/cobbler/settings
#  
default_password_crypted: "$1$centos$Uq6E6Wp5SDZYbs6MCmamP0"
manage_dhcp: 1
next_server: 10.1.1.10
server: 10.1.1.10
```
> [ settings  ()](/doc/cobbler-setting.txt)

## xinetd tftp
```
vi /etc/xinetd.d/tftp
#  disable = yes   disable = no
```

## dhcp
```
vi /etc/cobbler/dhcp.template
#  IP
#  DNSDNSPXE
# $next-server  /etc/cobbler/settings 
#
subnet 10.1.1.0 netmask 255.255.255.0 {
     option routers             10.1.1.2;
     option domain-name-servers 10.1.1.2;
     option subnet-mask         255.255.255.0;
     range dynamic-bootp        10.1.1.100 10.1.1.110;
     default-lease-time         21700;
     max-lease-time             43100;
     next-server                $next_server;

     class "pxeclients" {
          match if substring (option vendor-class-identifier, 0, 9) = "PXEClient";
          if option pxe-system-type = 00:02 {
              filename "ia64/elilo.efi";
          } else if option pxe-system-type = 00:06 {
              filename "grub/grub-x86.efi";
          } else if option pxe-system-type = 00:07 {
              filename "grub/grub-x86_64.efi";
          } else {
              filename "pxelinux.0";
          }
     }
}
```

> DHCP dhcpd  cobblerd  cobbler  dhcpd dhcpd.conf 
 `/etc/cobbler/settings`  `manage_dhcp: 1`  `0`  dhcp `/etc/dhcp/dhcpd.conf`

```
subnet 10.1.1.0 netmask 255.255.255.0 {
        option routers 10.1.1.2;
        option domain-name-servers 10.1.1.2;
        option subnet-mask 255.255.255.0;
        default-lease-time 21600;
        max-lease-time 43200;
        range 10.1.1.100 10.1.1.110;
        next-server 10.1.1.10;
        filename "pxelinux.0";
}
```

$1$centos$Uq6E6Wp5SDZYbs6MCmamP0

# cobbler
```
vi /etc/cobbler/settings
#  
default_password_crypted: "$1$centos$Uq6E6Wp5SDZYbs6MCmamP0"
manage_dhcp: 1
next_server: 10.1.1.10
server: 10.1.1.10
```
> [ settings  ()](/doc/cobbler-setting.txt)

## xinetd tftp
```
vi /etc/xinetd.d/tftp
#  disable = yes   disable = no
```

## dhcp
```
vi /etc/cobbler/dhcp.template
#  IP
#  DNSDNSPXE
# $next-server  /etc/cobbler/settings 
#
subnet 10.1.1.0 netmask 255.255.255.0 {
     option routers             10.1.1.2;
     option domain-name-servers 10.1.1.2;
     option subnet-mask         255.255.255.0;
     range dynamic-bootp        10.1.1.100 10.1.1.110;
     default-lease-time         21700;
     max-lease-time             43100;
     next-server                $next_server;

     class "pxeclients" {
          match if substring (option vendor-class-identifier, 0, 9) = "PXEClient";
          if option pxe-system-type = 00:02 {
              filename "ia64/elilo.efi";
          } else if option pxe-system-type = 00:06 {
              filename "grub/grub-x86.efi";
          } else if option pxe-system-type = 00:07 {
              filename "grub/grub-x86_64.efi";
          } else {
              filename "pxelinux.0";
          }
     }
}
```

# mpichblasatlashpl
VMVM

## mpich
 [MPI](http://www.mpich.org/static/downloads/3.2/mpich-3.2-installguide.pdf)  [MPI](http://www.mpich.org/static/downloads/3.2/mpich-3.2-userguide.pdf)
```
# 
yum install -y gcc gcc-gfortran gcc-c++ bzip2 wget

# yum mpich-3.2.x86_64libbinsrc
wget http://www.mpich.org/static/downloads/3.2/mpich-3.2.tar.gz
tar axf mpich-3.2.tar.gz
cd ~/mpich-3.2
./configure prefix=/opt/mpich
make -j 8 && make install  # makelibmake installlibbin

cp -r examples/ /opt/mpich/

# 
cd ~
tar zcf mpich-3.2-build.tar.gz /opt/mpich/
# 

echo 'export PATH=$PATH:/opt/mpich/bin'                         >> /etc/profile
echo 'export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$LD_LIBRARY_PATH:/opt/mpich/lib'   >> /etc/profile
source /etc/profile

# 
mpiexec -n 3 /opt/mpich/examples/cpi
```

mpiexecN -n  -f host_list_file 
mpiexecN
mpi
mpimpi

## BLAS, LINPACK/LAPACK, HPL
[BLASBasic Linear Algebra Subprograms- wiki](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basic_Linear_Algebra_Subprograms)  [BLAS - wiki](https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/BLAS) APINetlib BLASFortranNetlib ATLASIntel MKLACMLATLAS
```
wget https://downloads.sourceforge.net/project/math-atlas/Stable/3.10.3/atlas3.10.3.tar.bz2
tar axf atlas3.10.3.tar.bz2   # bzip2
cd ATLAS
mkdir build; cd build
../configure
make -j 8 && make install # /usr/local/atlas lib  include
# 
mkdir atlas
mv bin/ lib/ include/ atlas/
tar zcf atlas-build.tar.gz atlas/
```

[LINPACK](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LINPACK)BLAS[LAPACK](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LAPACK)[HPLinpackHighly Parallel Computing benchmarkHP](http://www.netlib.org/benchmark/hpl/)LINPACKGFPLOPS

 http://blog.chinaunix.net/uid-20104120-id-4071017.html 
```
wget http://www.netlib.org/benchmark/hpl/hpl-2.2.tar.gz
tar axf hpl-2.2.tar.gz
cd hpl-2.2
cp setup/Make.Linux_PII_CBLAS_gm Make.x86_64

#  Make.x86_64
# MPdir
#  
#  INCdirBINdirLIBdir$(ARCH)x86_64
ARCH         = x86_64

TOPdir       = $(HOME)/hpl-2.2
INCdir       = $(TOPdir)/include
BINdir       = $(TOPdir)/bin
LIBdir       = $(TOPdir)/lib

MPdir        =
MPinc        =
MPlib        =

LAdir        = /usr/local/atlas  # atlas make install
LAinc        = -I$(LAdir)/include
LAlib        = $(LAdir)/lib/libcblas.a $(LAdir)/lib/libatlas.a

# 
make arch=x86_64 -j 8

# 
mv hpl hpl.bk.d; mkdir hpl
mv bin/ lib/ include/ hpl/
rmdir hpl/bin/x86_64/ hpl/include/x86_64/ hpl/lib/x86_64/
tar zcf hpl-build.tar.gz hpl/
```

##  HPL
```
cd /root/hpl-2.2/hpl/bin/
mpiexec -n 4 ./xhpl  # 0.4GFLOPS
# HPL.dat
```

# Intel MKL Benchmarks
 https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/intel-mkl-benchmarks-suite 

```
wget http://registrationcenter-download.intel.com/akdlm/irc_nas/9752/l_mklb_p_2017.2.015.tgz
tar axf l_mklb_p_2017.2.015.tgz
cd l_mklb_p_2017.2.015/benchmarks_2017/linux/mkl/benchmarks/linpack
./runme_xeon64
```
 150GFLOPS
Windows

# Todo: mpi xhpl
 `l_mklb_p_2017.2.015/benchmarks_2017/linux/mkl/benchmarks/mp_linpack`  `runme_intel64_static`  perhost 
 `mpiexec -f hosts -n 12 ./xhpl_intel64_static`xhpl_intel64_staticHPL.dat/roothosts`top`xhpl_intel64_static4GFLOPSxhpl_intel64_static4MPIBLASIntel

+ [Intel MPI Library - Documentation](https://software.intel.com/zh-cn/articles/intel-mpi-library-documentation)
+ [Intel Optimized MP LINPACK Benchmark for Clusters](https://software.intel.com/en-us/node/528457)
+ [HPL application note](https://software.intel.com/en-us/articles/performance-tools-for-software-developers-hpl-application-note)
+ [HPC LINPACK benchmark](http://khmel.org/?p=527)
+ [LINPACK](http://blog.sciencenet.cn/blog-935970-892936.html)

```
auto lo
iface lo inet loopback

auto eno1
iface eno1 inet static
  address 2.2.2.140
  netmask 255.255.255.0
  network 2.2.2.0
  broadcast 2.2.2.255
  # gateway 2.2.2.1
  up ip route add 2.2.0.0/16   via 2.2.2.1 || true
  up ip route add 2.2.2.0/24   via 2.2.2.1 || true
  up ip route add 172.0.0.0/8  via 2.2.2.1 || true

# The primary network interface
auto eno2
iface eno2 inet static
  address 10.0.0.140
  netmask 255.255.255.0
  network 10.0.0.0
  broadcast 10.0.0.255
  gateway 10.0.0.147
  # dns-* options are implemented by the resolvconf package, if installed
  dns-nameservers 233.5.5.5
```

# SquidHTTP

## Squid
`n147`IP`2.2.2.147`Squid
```
yum install -y squid # CentOS
apt install -y squid # Ubuntu
apk add squid     # Alpine

# squid /etc/squid/squid.conf Dockerfile

# squid
squid -z

# 
systemctl enable squid
systemctl start  squid
```

## DockerSquid
Dockerfile
```
FROM alpine:latest

RUN apk update --no-cache; \
    apk add squid --no-cache

# squid.confIPIP
RUN sed  -i "/RFC 4291/a acl ics src 2.2.2.0/24" squid.conf; \
    sed  -i "/RFC 4291/a acl ics src 2.2.3.3/32" squid.conf

#  EXPOSE 
RUN sed -i "/http_port/c http_port 8888" squid.conf

# cache
RUN sed -i '/cache_dir/s/#//g' /etc/squid/squid.conf

# 
# ADD squid.conf /etc/squid/squid.conf

# squid -zcacheDockerfile
# RUN squid -z
# cachesquid
# 

RUN echo -e '#!/bin/sh\n[ -d /var/cache/squid/00 ] || squid -z\nsquid -N' >/squid.sh; \
    chmod +x /squid.sh

EXPOSE 3128
CMD ["/squid.sh"]
```

`docker build ./ -t squid:latest`
`docker run -d -p 3128:3128 --name squid squid:latest`


# HTTP
`n147`

## 
`/etc/environment``export``/etc/profile``/etc/profile.d/http_proxy.sh``http_proxy``https_proxy`
```
export http_proxy=http://2.2.2.147:3128
export https_proxy=http://2.2.2.147:3128
```

`squid`https `https_proxy=http://2.2.2.147:3128` `http://`

## Docker
Docker[](https://docs.docker.com/engine/admin/systemd/)`/etc/systemd/system/docker.service.d/http-proxy.conf`
```
[Service]
Environment="HTTP_PROXY=http://2.2.2.147:3128" "HTTPS_PROXY=http://2.2.2.147:3128"  "NO_PROXY=localhost,10.0.0.147"
```
docker daemon `systemctl restart docker``docker info`

## yum
yum `/etc/yum.conf`
```
proxy=http://2.2.2.147:3128
```

## apt
`/etc/apt/apt.conf`
```
Acquire::http::proxy  "http://2.2.2.147:3128";
Acquire::https::proxy "http://2.2.2.147:3128";
```

## CAP

Paper
+ [Eventual Consistency Today - Limitations, Extensions,and Beyond - CACM1305](http://queue.acm.org/detail.cfm?id=2462076)
+ [Replicated Data Consistency Explained Through Baseball - CACM1312](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/research/publication/replicated-data-consistency-explained-through-baseball/)[](/doc/CACM1312_Replicated_Data_Consistency_Explained_Through_Baseball.pdf)
+ [Quantifying Eventual Consistency with PBS - CACM1408](www.bailis.org/papers/pbs-vldbj2014.pd)[PBS ](/doc/CACM1408_Quantifying_Eventual_Consistency_with_PBS.pdf)[Peter Bailis](http://www.bailis.org/)
+ [Probabilistically-Atomic 2-Atomicity: Enabling Almost Strong Consistency in Distributed Storage Systems](http://cs.nju.edu.cn/yuhuang/huangyufiles/papers/2017-pa2a-tc.pdf) [IEEE Xplore](http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/7547362/)
+ [PhD14 - Benchmarking Eventually Consistent Distributed Storage System - David Bermbach](https://www.ksp.kit.edu/9783731501862)
+ [IEEE Computer - ( Vol. 45 Issue 2 ) The CAP Theorem's Growing Impact](http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/tocresult.jsp?isnumber=6155638)
+ [A Critique of the CAP Theorem](https://arxiv.org/abs/1509.05393)
> The CAP Theorem is a frequently cited impossibility result in distributed systems, especially among NoSQL distributed databases. In this paper we survey some of the confusion about the meaning of CAP, including inconsistencies and ambiguities in its definitions, and we highlight some problems in its formalization. CAP is often interpreted as proof that eventually consistent databases have better availability properties than strongly consistent databases; although there is some truth in this, we show that more careful reasoning is required. These problems cast doubt on the utility of CAP as a tool for reasoning about trade-offs in practical systems. As alternative to CAP, we propose a "delay-sensitivity" framework, which analyzes the sensitivity of operation latency to network delay, and which may help practitioners reason about the trade-offs between consistency guarantees and tolerance of network faults.

> The CAP Theorem is a frequently cited impossibility result in distributed systems, especially among NoSQL distributed databases. In this paper we survey some of the confusion about the meaning of CAP, including inconsistencies and ambiguities in its definitions, and we highlight some problems in its formalization. CAP is often interpreted as proof that eventually consistent databases have better availability properties than strongly consistent databases; although there is some truth in this, we show that more careful reasoning is required. These problems cast doubt on the utility of CAP as a tool for reasoning about trade-offs in practical systems. As alternative to CAP, we propose a "delay-sensitivity" framework, which analyzes the sensitivity of operation latency to network delay, and which may help practitioners reason about the trade-offs between consistency guarantees and tolerance of network faults.
